column1: Scientific or technial assistant / (f/div/m) in Synthetic Biology or Biotechnology
for one year initially.
Research Areas: Molecular Biology
column2: Biochemistry
column3: Biotechnology
column4: Dictyostelium discoideum

column1: This project is part of a Federal Ministry for Education and Research (BMBF) funded research project which aims to develop the social amoeba Dictyostelium discoideum into a production platform for secondary metabolites of pharmaceutical importance..
The field of study:

The successful candidate will assist in the construction of multi-gene expression plasmids and the establishment of CRISPR/Cas tools for strain engineering of the social amoeba Dictyostelium discoideum and will help to develop methods to measure and enhance the production of heterologous secondary metabolites.
The main topics of the project may include:
• Metabolic engineering of D. discoideum to enhance the production of biochemical precursors for polyketide production
• High-throughput cultivations
column2: automated screening and processing of production strains of D. discoideum

• A bachelor or master degree in molecular biology

column3: microbiology
column4: biotechnology or related discipline. Candidates about to obtain their degree are welcome to apply.

• The candidate should be highly interested in applied

column3: interdisciplinary research team.

column1: We offer:

Group Leader – Structural or Molecular Systems Biology;"The Structural and Computational Biology (SCB) Unit at EMBL Heidelberg pursues an ambitious and cross-disciplinary research program in integrated structural and computational systems biology
column2: bridging between temporal and spatial scales. The SCB Unit seeks to recruit a highly motivated group leader in the area of structural or molecular systems biology to address fundamental questions in life sciences.

column1: Your role
Establish an independent and innovative research programme. The SCB Unit is interested in attracting candidates that pursue experimental or computational approaches
column2: which can contribute to or interface with integrated structural biology. Research areas can be diverse including chemical biology
column3: (high-throughput) biochemistry
column4: biophysics
column5: proteomics
column6: metabolomics
column8: modelling and simulation of biological systems. The research should extend or enrich structural systems biology
column9: a broad concept that the unit is pursuing
column10: in conjunction with a strong computational biology programme.

column1: In line with EMBL’s scientific programme from Molecules to Ecosystems
column2: the SCB Unit is also interested in candidates that have research programs related to EMBL’s transversal themes; for example
column3: the SCB Unit has already considerable strengths in Planetary Biology and Microbial Ecosystems. The future group leader will be embedded in the multidisciplinary and collaborative environment of EMBL
column4: which provides many opportunities for interaction with other research groups.

column1: You have
The ambition to work on fundamental biological questions
column2: which implies both
column3: biological discoveries or methodological advances. Furthermore
column4: your research complements and synergizes with the activities of the SCB Unit and the whole of EMBL. You should therefore demonstrate a strong motivation to work in the collaborative and multidisciplinary environment of EMBL.

column1: In addition
column2: you should be dedicated to develop effective relationships and to provide leadership and guidance to team members. The ability to work independently and to participate in a collaborative team effort is desirable
column3: as is a pro-active and positive problem-solving mind-set.

column1: You might also have
EMBL’s new program
column2: Molecules to Ecosystems
column3: includes a vision to advance our understanding of ecosystems at the molecular level
column4: applying expertise in molecular biology to study life in its natural context. New research areas will focus on applying experimental
column5: computational and theoretical approaches to study at multiple levels (molecules
column6: cells
column7: tissues and populations) how organisms interact with each other and respond to environmental change. SCB will be happy to host structural or molecular systems biology activities related to the new transversal themes.

column1: • Planetary Biology – aiming to understand how microbes
column2: plants
column3: and animals interact with each other and with their abiotic environments at the molecular level.

column1: • Microbial Ecosystems – studying microorganisms
column2: how they live in communities and interact with their environments
column3: including host organisms.

column1: • Infection Biology – unravelling new strategies to treat infections by studying pathogens
column2: their molecular machineries
column3: their interface with the host
column4: and their ability to spread in populations and across hosts.

column1: • Human Ecosystems – applying computational and experimental approaches to reveal the impact of the environment on human health and physiology
column2: both at the individual and the population level.

column1: • Theory – using modelling
column2: mathematical reasoning
column3: and conceptual approaches to study complex and dynamic biological systems.

column1: • Why join us

EMBL appoints group leaders from early on in their career and provides a very supportive environment for your first independent position in order to achieve your research goals. The initial “Lead your Lab” management training is provided for all incoming group leaders.

The SCB Unit at EMBL offers access to an outstanding integrated structural biology environment that includes a particularly well equipped cryo-electron microscopy facility. The Unit also interacts closely with the EMBL Imaging Centre that offers access to a broad spectrum of electron and light microscopy technologies with special emphasis on correlative approaches. Further information about research in the SCB Unit and at EMBL can be found at the EMBL web page.
EMBL is curiosity-driven
column2: community-oriented and international. As an inclusive
column3: equal opportunity employer
column4: we believe that diversity enables us to collaborate more effectively and be innovative in our approaches. We are
column5: therefore
column6: committed to creating an inclusive and flexible culture – one where everyone can realise their full potential and make a positive contribution to our organisation.

column1: We encourage applications from individuals who can complement our existing team – we believe that success is built on having teams whose backgrounds and personal experiences reflect the diversity of the populations that our science serves. We actively encourage applications from all genders and cultures
column2: ethnic groups and all demographics to help us avoid perpetuating biases and oversights at this transformational point in our people strategy.

column1: EMBL offers attractive conditions and benefits appropriate to an international research organisation with a very collegial and family-friendly working environment. Competitive salary and social security benefits
column2: financial support for relocation
column3: a relaxed culture
column4: professional development
column5: an on-site nursery
column6: canteen and other staff facilities make EMBL a great place to work.

column1: What else you need to know
We are Europe’s flagship research laboratory for the life sciences – an intergovernmental organisation performing scientific research in disciplines including molecular biology
column2: physics
column3: chemistry and computer science. We are an international
column4: innovative and interdisciplinary laboratory with more than 1800 employees from more than 80 countries
column5: operating across six sites

column1: Postdoc Biology - membrane electron transport (m/f/d);"The Helmholtz Centre for Environmental Research (UFZ) with its 1
column2: 100 employees has gained an excellent reputation as an international competence centre for environmental sciences. We are part of the largest scientific organisation in Germany
column3: the Helmholtz Association. Our mission: Our research seeks to find a balance between social development and the long-term protection of our natural resources. Hydrogen will play a key role in decarbonizing our society and sustaining our future. Biophotovoltaics (BPV)
column4: which exploits the natural oxygenic photosystem in a bioelectrochemcial system
column5: aims to deliver a sustainble solution for hydrogen production in the future. It provides unique benefits in terms of the energy and resource demands and also it can potentially make H2 production as a carbon-sink process since the oxygenic photomicroorganism (e.g. cyanobacteria) use CO2 as the carbon source for growth and maintenance. Within the newly BMBF funded Nachwuchsgruppenprojekt BioPV4H2
column6: we aim to gain a holistic understanding of the BPV process from both biological and technological aspects
column7: and thus to promote rational design and development of this technique for future application. To realize the proposed ambitious goals
column8: I am seeking an enthusiastic synthetic biologist to fill a full-time postdoc position funded by this project. The main task of this position is to engineer the membrane electron transfer pathways of cyanobacteria in BPV using synthetic biology tools
column9: in order to facilitate the electron transfer rate from the photosystem to the external electron sink. The successful candidate will have the support to establish and lead the synthetic biology platform in the group
column10: and will be strongly supported to develop his/her research profile for the next scientific career move
column11: including but not limited to further training
column12: international conference and networking. Postdoc position (m/f/x) on engineering the membrane electron transport pathway in Synechocystis Working time: 100% (39 hours per week)
column14: 2023 but can be discussed upon individual case. (The initial phase of employment will be 1 year
column15: and will be directly extended for another 3 years upon positive evaluation.) The successful candidate will develop and lead the synthetic biology platform
column16: and work closely with the PhD students and also our project partners (e.g. Prof. Victor de Lorenzo and Prof. Peter Lindblad) to drive the research progress of the respective working tasks. Particularly your tasks will include: Developing the synthetic biology methods for bacterial membrane protein expression and knock-down/out; Introducing heterologous membrane reductase to extract electrons from cellular electron transport chain; Characterizing the microbial physiology and behaviors; Communicating with our project partners and also involved in preparing the strategic plan of the project; Co-supervising PhD/Master/Bachelor students; Presenting project progress at international scientific conferences; Writing progress report
column17: and publishing project results in high-ranked scientific journals; PhD in molecular biology
column19: biochemistry or related area; Documented experience in synthetic biology method development; Documented experience in strain engineering
column20: best on the cyanobacteria or microalgae; Experience with bacterial membrane protein expression
column21: CRISPR or CRISPRi will be a bonus; Knowledge in quantitative biology using omics and/or microscopy-based tools will be an asset
column22: but not essential; Knowledge in pure culture-based bioelectrochemical systems will be beneficial
column23: but not essential; Excellent communication and team-working skills; Capable of critical thinking and able to work independently; Strong self-motivation for scientific work in an interdisciplinary project; Proficient in English speaking and writing. The Position
Senior Associate Genomic Medicines (m/f/d)
Are you ready for your next challenge?
Our vision is to create novel and highly differentiated medicines. To this end
column2: we discover and

column1: develop novel therapeutic antibodies and next generation biologics
column2: such as bispecific

column1: antibodies
column2: fusion proteins or AAV vectors for gene therapy. Our ambition is to deliver such

column1: novel molecules to patients with game changing clinical benefits.
We are looking for a Senior Associate in Genomic Medicine (m/f/d) with a keen interest in the
fields of drug discovery and development. You will join the department of Cell Technologies
which belongs to a unit called Large Molecule Research within Roche Pharma Research and
Early Development (pRED).
This position therefore offers the opportunity to interact with numerous functions within
Roche to deliver novel medicines to patients.
Your team in a nutshell:
You will be part of ambitious matrix teams
column2: which drive different projects of the Genomic

column1: Medicine in Therapeutic Modalities (TMo). These teams involve Roche colleagues with
different expertise and level (e.g. students
column2: lab technicians
column3: scientists and project managers).

column1: Each voice is valued and we highly appreciate the contribution of different perspectives that
often leads to innovative solutions for our challenging projects.
The job in a nutshell:
Your work focuses on development and application of methods for AAV vector generation for
Gene Therapy. Hereby you will employ synthetic biology tools for cell engineering and
recombinant AAV vector engineering. You have a strong background in molecular biology
analytical methods
column2: and cell-culture & -engineering. In addition
column3: you can establish methods

column1: that enable design-build-test-learn cycles for the development of advanced AAV vectors.
Moreover
column2: you have strong organizational skills as you will be responsible for structuring and

column1: maintaining lab activities.
The main tasks of this position:
DESIGN: You will design experiments for optimization of AAV-vectors and AAV-vector
production systems (including stable production cell lines) & workflows (including
automated workflows) supported by using methodologies such as used in Synthetic
Biology.
BUILD: You will apply cutting-edge technology to design and create plasmids and
AAV vectors by either using internal capabilities or by using external suppliers.
TEST: You will use existing and establish new functional readouts
column2: e.g. dPCR
column3: FACS

column1: reporter cell systems
column2: microfluidic systems and NGS for the characterization of

column1: AAV-vectors and AAV-vector production systems and workflows.
LEARN: You will use state-of-the-art data analysis software to analyze and
consolidate large data sets that support informed or AI-guided decision-making for the
next design cycle.
You will be responsible to map standardized biological parts and process large data
sets to fit into our IT infrastructure.
This is also very important for us:
Team player: you are passionate about building strong teams. In your teams
column2: everyone

column1: shares the success while setbacks are viewed as an opportunity to learn. You support
temporary workers and / or interns.
Communication and networking: You know how to proactively build bridges and how to
network in a big organization.
Being courageous: you tackle difficult issues with confidence and you hold things together
during tough times.
Organizational awareness: you see the big picture and have a clear understanding of other
group's business needs.
Continuous learning: you enjoy the challenges of unfamiliar tasks to continuously learn new
things. You seek novel approaches to solve problems and to challenge the status quo.
Presentation skills: you know how to present in a clear and convincing way in front of big
audiences and management boards.
And the technical requirements for this position?
A strong background in cutting-edge technologies for AAV-vector generation and
biology
column2: cell engineering & synthetic biology is necessary for this position.

column1: Postdoctoral Researcher – Synthetic Biology (m

column3: d)

column1: Full-time
column2: initially limited to 2 yearsWe are looking for an outstanding individual to drive a visionary synthetic biology project poised to make an impact in oncology. With its emphasis on well-characterized and standardized parts
column3: synthetic biology is considered the engineering approach to building molecular systems. It enables the creation of entirely new molecular functionality in a modular and systematic fashion. The project aims to design intelligent therapeutic gene circuits that can detect and regulate pathophysiological expression of non-coding RNA in tumor cells in a precise and reliable manner. Computational experts in the hosting lab will support the design of those circuits through data analysis
column4: mathematical modeling and machine learning. The project is a joint venture cooperation between TU Darmstadt and Belgian Biotech Studio
column5: eureKASYNBIO (part of the investment company eureKARE) with its special focus on synthetic biology. The selected candidate will be employed by the joint venture and will be located at TU Darmstadt for an initial period of two years. The candidate is given the opportunity to take a leading role in the formation of the envisioned startup company.
